newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Irish govt seeks moderate wages and low inflation.
newsitem.headline: Irish govt seeks moderate wages and low inflation.

text.p: The Irish government said on Tuesday that it hopes to maintain a stable, moderate wage and low inflation environment, on the eve of negotiations for a new Programme for Competitiveness and Work (PCW).
In a statement accompanying the 1996 labour force survey, the government said that over the life of the PCW, 130,000 jobs were created -- more than in the preceding 20 years.
The PCW, agreed in 1993, included a wage agreement reached through a consensus approach by government, employers and unions to the management of the economy, known as social partership.

That agreement is due to expire at the end of 1996 and negotiations on a new agreement begin on October 23. "In the forthcoming discussions ... the government will be seeking to maintain, in conjunction with the social partners, a stable, moderate wage and low inflation environment to promote further job creation," the government said.

A labour force survey, published on Tuesday, showed an increase of 45,000 in employment in the year to mid-April which the government said was largely due to adhering to a prudent Programme for Competitiveness and Work (PCW) over the last three years.
Apart from Scandinavia, Ireland has the highest level of trade union membership among EU countries at more than 50 percent of the workforce.
Trade union penetration of the private sector stands at around 35 percent as against 90 percent in the public sector.

It is expected that unions and employers will adopt a tougher stance in the forthcoming negotiations, demanding significant tax cuts and tight control of public spending before they sign up for any new agreement.
The government said the favourable macro-economic conditions currently enjoyed by Ireland was also a boost to increasing the numbers employed.
Ireland's gross domestic product is expected to grow by six percent in 1996. It grew at 10 percent in 1995 and is deemed the fastest growing economy within the European Union.
